body: For three days, New Yorkers could not watch the closing doors, could not try to make sense of garbled announcements, could not wonder why the express always pulls out just as the local pulls in. So the news that transit workers were going back to work left many New Yorkers thinking one of those only-in-New-York thoughts: a subway car is a beautiful
title: TRANSIT STRIKE ENDS: VOICES; Grudging Praise for a System Riders Say They Can't Live Without

body: A contractor who had been hired to tear down a garage behind a Brooklyn home was found dead yesterday under a collapsed wall at the site, the authorities said. It was not clear how long the contractor, identified by the authorities as Frederick E. Lopez, 32, of Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, had been dead, but residents on East 32nd Street in Midwood,
title: Contractor's Body Is Found In Rubble of Garage Wall

body: At least four people, including a city firefighter, were seriously injured early yesterday in a blaze at an apartment building in Brooklyn that forced a 16-year-old girl to jump out of a third-floor window, the authorities and residents said. The girl, whose name was not released, and her father, identified by neighbors as Dupree Corbett, 58, were
title: Fire in Brooklyn Injures Four, Including a Girl Who Jumped From a Third-Floor Window

body: Thanksgiving is always a busy time for Julie Sorokurs. She and her younger sister, Cathy, help in the kitchen with the apple pie, mixing the flour and remembering, Julie said, to ''take turns so everything is fair.'' Then they work on the day's costumes, assembling Pilgrim hats out of black construction paper. During dinner, she is happy to
title: Children Lead Pilgrims of Today In Cultural Lessons

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: He walked these avenues and then he was gone, as the inhabitants of one city give way to the next, as some are hurried along. Everyone leaves behind a name, a time, a place and a role, and his were Jimmy Moy, 1960, Park Slope, Brooklyn: the man who never returned. A cataclysm's sudden vacancy leaves the memory of the disappeared, and the great
title: Tracing Steps of the Man Who Walked Away

body: MEYER--Trude (nee Nassau) January 1, 1910, at 95. Beloved mother of Rita and Ronny Meyer. Devoted wife of Allen. Loving daughter of Rose and Louis Nassau and Tetta to Lewis and Harold Nassau. Charter member and former vice president of neighborhood chapter of B'nai B'rith and member of the East Midwood Jewish Center. Kind and caring friend to so
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MEYER, TRUDE (NEE NASSAU)

body: COBEN -- Grace. Beloved mother of Dr. Flora and Elliott Bloom. Dear grandmother of Dr. Lisa Ellen Bloom and Dr. Peter Jason Bloom; fond sister of Sidney and Lucille Cole. body: KAY--Helen Dorothy. Died on October 4, 2005 at the age of 103. Before marrying Irving Kay on October 3, 1926 she wrote and acted in plays and short stories and received professional offers. As a conscientious wife and mother of two sons she still became an outstanding handball player and worker in a war time naval hospital. Afterwards, she was a
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KAY, HELEN DOROTHY

body: Rarely does anyone see peaches labeled by type: yellow, white, local and doughnut are usually as far as it goes. But the Indian blood peach, a velvet-skinned late-season variety, is worth seeking. Its burgundy flesh, shading to gold, is deeply flavored and juicy. Goldbud Farms in Placerville, Calif., ships Indian bloods to the Orchard, 1367 Coney
title: FOOD STUFF; Voluptuary in a Velvet Glove

body: Two critical contests on the Sept. 13 Democratic primary ballot in Brooklyn -- for district attorney and for a Surrogate's Court judgeship -- offer voters a chance to register their disgust with the cozy clubhouse-courthouse ties that lie at the heart of the borough's judicial patronage and corruption scandal, and the undue influence of Clarence
title: For Cleaner Courts in Brooklyn

body: HERB PREMINGER, a courteous, soft-eyed man who lives on East 17th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, has managed well during his professional life as a marketing writer. But for nearly three decades, his overwhelming passion has been for his work as an amateur historian of the vanished New York candy store. In his living room one day recently, Mr.
title: THE VOICE; His Madeleine, the Cherry Lime Rickey

body: Congressman Anthony D. Weiner will begin running the first television advertisement of his mayoral campaign tomorrow. The ad, a 30-second spot, will be shown on cable and network television and will run through Aug. 29. Mr. Weiner is spending $686,178 to show it. PRODUCER -- GMMB. ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with Mr. Weiner standing over a
title: THE AD CAMPAIGN; Weiner Takes a Swing

body: Starting this week, American Jews are likely to see wrenching scenes of Jewish soldiers expelling defiant Jewish settlers from their homes and farms in the Gaza Strip, as Israel begins its pullout there. The experience for many Americans will be almost as painful and perplexing as it will be for Israelis, because the two societies are so
title: American Jews Sharing Pain Of Gaza Pullout

body: A fire early yesterday in Manhattan killed a 94-year-old man who had been confined to his fifth-floor walkup apartment because of a hip injury, fire officials and neighbors said. Firefighters carried the man, identified by neighbors as Nicholas DeCurtis, out of the fire in his apartment on Christopher Street about 2 a.m. yesterday, neighbors said.
title: Fire Kills Man, 94, Confined To Apartment by an Injured Hip

body: To the Editor: ''Take This $100 Million. Please'' does not mention the following points: The Taub Urban Research Center study ''Tunnel Vision'' concluded that ''the proposed hub port and rail tunnel are Industrial Era Projects ill suited for the information economy of the 21st century. Furthermore, the proposed hub port and rail tunnel represent a
title: The Rail Tunnel, Pro and Con

body: The investigation into the macabre death on Wednesday night of a young woman on Staten Island -- first thought to be the result of a panicked burglar turning to homicide -- took a different direction yesterday, and the authorities are now looking into the possibility that the victim had previously met her killer, a law enforcement official said.
title: S.I. Death Inquiry Focuses on Victim's History

body: Theater 'SANGO (LORD OF THUNDER),' a West African coming-of-age dance-drama, by the Orisha Tales Repertory Radio Theater Company and the Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, at 120th Street, Morningside Heights, (212)870-6784. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25; children, $15. Through Aug. 28. Events
title: SPARE TIMES; For Children

body: It emerged in the 1960's as an invention born of fear: the taxicab partition, meant to spare the lives of drivers at a time of gunfire, armed robberies and murders. Over its lifetime, it would become yellowed and defaced; its contraption for safely passing money to the driver would often break down. And with the partition closed, the classic cabbie
title: Taxi Partitions, Born of Danger, May Be Set For a Makeover

body: BLOCK--Norman Jacob. Of Brooklyn, NY on July 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Carole. Loving father of Gail Block Harris and Ira Jay Block. Dear father-in-law of Walter Harris & Madelon Rosenfeld. Adoring grandfather of Katherine Clark Harris and Jennifer Leigh Harris. President of Carole Block, Ltd. Past President of Avenue M Merchants Association.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BLOCK, NORMAN JACOB

body: For 8, 10, sometimes 14 hours a day, they wipe apple juice off sticky chins, chide wobbly toddlers lurching toward a staircase, snuggle dusty 2-year-olds as they make their way from the playground. It bewildered some rescue workers on Thursday to realize that the tiny child buried beneath the rubble of a building that had just collapsed on
title: City Nannies Say They, Too, Can Be Mother Lions

body: Ever since the police and the medical technicians came and took the woman's body away from the backyard on East 15th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, on Monday, people have been waiting to hear what really happened. The police are saying little, other than that the woman has not been identified. A spokeswoman for the medical examiner said yesterday
title: In Brooklyn, Little Light on Mystery of a Body in a Yard

body: A man returning home yesterday afternoon discovered a dead woman in his backyard, the police said. The body was discovered shortly before 4 p.m. in the backyard of 1542 East 15th Street, in Midwood. The police said that the woman was dark-skinned, had long black hair and was clad only in a shirt. The body was taken to the medical examiner's office
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Found In Backyard

body: To the Editor: Having grown up in the Midwood section and still counting as my closest friends two ''girls'' who went to P.S. 193 and Midwood High School with me, I loved your series of articles on Brooklyn. To celebrate our 75th birthdays, the three of us recently took a nostalgia trip to see our former schools, homes and neighborhood. We were
title: Memories of Midwood

body: To the Editor: As a third-generation Brooklynite, I enjoyed your City section devoted to Brooklyn. What I don't enjoy are the attitudes held by many newcomers. Too many tend to overlook or even look down on natives and especially our ''unhip'' neighborhoods such as Midwood, Gravesend and Mill Basin. One Fort Greene mom rolled her eyes and told me
title: 'Unhip'? Oh, Please

author: Humera Afridi is completing her first novel, ''Asymptotes,'' set in New York, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.
body: CONEY ISLAND is what they call it. ''Our new home -- Coney Island,'' they say proudly and flick their eyes toward the double-wide avenue lined with squat two- and three-story buildings huddled together like members of an ambushed army. The short stretch of Coney Island Avenue from Avenue H to Beverly Road, along with the side streets leading off
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; The Coney Island Of Their Mind

body: A Brooklyn man stabbed his stepdaughter's friend at his apartment house and set fire to the building with 13 people inside early yesterday, killing two of his tenants and himself, the police said. The man, Barrington King, 47, was found dead, along with his tenants, Yolanda Fredericks, 54, and Herbert Simmons-St. Louis, 60, inside the brick
title: Police Say Man Set a Deadly Fire After a Family Fight

body: THE leafy, sleepy Midwood neighborhood of Brooklyn is as green, clean and quiet as it was in the late 1950's, when Willa Gelber was a teenager and itchy for more sophisticated urban pleasures. Her family lived in that Midwood archetype, a large 1950's stucco two-family house with a front porch, a backyard and a finished basement, along with a dark
title: HABITATS/Midwood, Brooklyn; Discovering You Can Go Home Again

author: Yisrael Feuerman is an organizational consultant and psychotherapist who lives in Passaic.
body: WHEN I told my rebbe in Brooklyn that I was moving to Passaic, he said: ''What do you have there? You'll never find Torah like we have here.'' For good measure, he added, ''And it won't be good for the children.'' He was referring not to a particular synagogue or school or house of study. He was not even referring to the legions of men in Brooklyn
title: SOAPBOX; Out of Brooklyn

body: Dressed in a navy suit and red tie, his hair parted neatly on the side, Special Agent Charles E. Frahm sat with practiced calm as Muslims rose, one after another, to hurl raw complaints at him. Mr. Frahm, who heads the counterterrorism division of the F.B.I. in New York, was at a banquet hall in the Midwood section of Brooklyn on Thursday night to
title: You Can't Talk to an F.B.I. Agent That Way, or Can You?

body: Assemblyman Dov Hikind and the president of New York City Transit, Lawrence G. Reuter, announced yesterday that 120 closed-circuit television cameras were installed last month at nine subway stations along the D, F and N lines in Brooklyn. Mr. Hikind, a Brooklyn Democrat, used $1.2 million in discretionary funds available to Assembly members for
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Security Cameras In Stations

body: The new face of New York City is taking shape among the graceful Victorian houses and stout apartment buildings of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. This softly shaded patch of Flatbush is one of the city's most polyglot and polychrome, what city demographers like to call a melting-pot neighborhood, because no one ethnic or racial group is dominant and many
title: Brooklyn's Technicolor Dream Quilt

author: John Mollenkopf is a professor at the City University of New York and director of its Center for Urban Research.
body: BOTH presidential campaigns allotted New York State to John Kerry in 2004, largely because New York City was rightly perceived as among the bluest -- or most Democratic -- areas in the country. After all, Democrats enjoy a 5-to-1 registration advantage over Republicans in the city. In 2000, only 18 percent of the city's voters cast their ballots
title: Painting the Town Red

body: FOR those lacking cab-ride entertainment since television screens were discontinued in taxis in 2003, there is hope. It comes in the form of the Human Computer, a k a Oleg Roitman, an immigrant cabdriver from Ukraine who regales fares with a flashy sleight of mind: Give Mr. Roitman any date -- say, your birthday -- and within a second, he will tell
title: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Entertainer

body: BILOFSKY--Pearl. Devoted wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Walter and Ellen Bilofsky. Mother-in-law of David Newman and Nancy Bilofsky. Adored grandmother of Jessica and Alexander Newman. Services 1:30 Wednesday at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Ave M).
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BILOFSKY, PEARL

body: GREGORY ZASLAVSKY, a Russian entrepreneur with black hair, fine skin and a gravelly voice, describes his 28 years of achievement in New York with no small amount of pride: the Brighton Beach restaurant, the supermarkets. But the venture of which Mr. Zaslavsky is proudest, and the only one in which he still has a hand, is the Russian bathhouse on
title: URBAN TACTICS; Banya Fever

body: It was not your everyday high school reunion, and not just because everybody in the room was over 80 years old. Sure, there were some obligatory reunion moments and many chances to reconnect with the earnest follies of long ago. Bob Lachman, deeply tanned from his annual winter in Florida, fruitlessly scanned the room once again for the girl who
title: How Long Has It Been? 2 Months; Class of 1940 Doesn't Wait Years to Reunite

body: Sixteen school custodians were arrested yesterday on charges of taking kickbacks from corrupt vendors who were paid for cleaning products and other supplies that were never delivered. The custodians were charged with misappropriating federal funds, a felony, among other counts. In all, investigators estimated that several hundred thousand dollars
title: 16 Custodians In City Schools Are Accused Of Corruption

body: Two bags containing what the police believe to be human remains were discovered yesterday afternoon next to a stairway leading to the Long Island Rail Road tracks near Ocean Avenue in Midwood, Brooklyn, the police said. The police did not describe the remains, or say when they thought they had been left. The medical examiner's office is examining
title: Grisly Discovery Near Train Tracks

body: WHAT do you get when you sell a three-bedroom, 1,500-square-foot Brooklyn Heights co-op for $1 million and buy a seven-bedroom, 4,000-square-foot house 10 minutes away in Prospect Park South for $1.025 million? According to Felicia Kang, who, with her husband, Tom Rosenthal, just made that move, you get a terrific bargain with lots more room -- and
title: LIVING IN/Prospect Park South, Brooklyn; Near Prospect Park, a Touch of Greenwich

body: A bizarre chain-reaction crash at a Brooklyn intersection during the morning rush yesterday sent a small school bus hurtling onto the sidewalk and into a young woman, crushing her against an apartment building wall and killing her, the police and witnesses said. The accident, which occurred just before 9 a.m. at the corner of Ocean Avenue and
title: Chain Reaction Leaves a Pedestrian Dead

body: More students were admitted to their first choice for high school this year than last, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday, and 4,000 fewer students than last year will face the disappointment of not being admitted to any of their top 12 choices. The chancellor said the figures proved that a new high school admissions process,
title: More Students Admitted To High School of Choice

body: To the Editor: Your March 13 editorial supporting a rail link under New York Harbor does not mention its drawbacks. Objections come not just from Maspeth, Queens, but from other affected areas such as Jersey City and Bay Ridge, Sunset Park, Borough Park and Midwood in Brooklyn. Noise, dirt and threats to the structural integrity of buildings will
title: Cross-Harbor Rail Link

body: As he traveled through Jerusalem this week for a national commemoration of the Holocaust, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave only glancing public voice to his own Judaism -- for example, saying jokingly to the mayor of Jerusalem that his grandfather ''would fall asleep'' during family Seders when he was a child back in Massachusetts. But in an
title: Bloomberg, in Israel Trip, Shies Away From Religiosity

author: sgfreedman@nytimes.com
body: ABOUNDING in hope and anxiety, Jessie Streich-Kest started the process of applying to college last week. With all the other juniors at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, she received an information booklet about several dozen institutions and three standard forms for recommendation letters. Very soon, a guidance counselor told Jessie, she
title: ON EDUCATION; Student Grades? The Computers Flunk

body: NEWMAN--Anne Margulies. Died peacefully at home in West Palm Beach March 6, 2005, at age 91. Beloved wife of 56 years of the late Dr. Herbert Newman. Devoted mother of Robert, Donald and Carol, cherished motherin-law of Vivien, and loving friend of long-term caregiver Delores Waite. A child of immigrants, Anne was first in her family to attend
title: Paid Notice: Deaths NEWMAN, ANNE MARGULIES

author: Ed Levine is the author of the recently published ''Pizza: A Slice of Heaven'' (Universe Publishing, $24.95).
body: ALL over the country, from Phoenix to New York to New Haven, pizza is now made by obsessed creative types on a mission, eaten by sophisticated diners who appreciate the nuances of the perfect pie, and discussed in hushed tones by adoring fans and pizza lovers who talk of the different schools of pizza-making as if they are comparing Monet and
title: The Sacred Art of Pizza Making, and Secrets to Perfect Pies

author: Jay Dixit writes for The Washington Post, The Village Voice and Rolling Stone.
body: WHEN Joey Gay heard that Pips Comedy Club in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, was for sale, he discovered his life's purpose. All the elements of his past -- growing up with an embarrassing last name in a rough part of Brooklyn, learning to be funny to ward off schoolyard bullies, running a strip club for five years and doing standup for eight --
title: Joey Gay's Excellent Adventure

body: COHEN--Judith. Loving wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Ellen Sue Cohen. Adored grandmother of Dani Beth Turk. Dear great-aunt of Brett Kingstone. Sister of Ann Skolnick. Services Sunday, March 6, 10 AM, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

body: WHILE Columbia University struggles to find the line between academic freedom and unacceptable classroom behavior, the city's Department of Education has found a facile but provocative solution: banish the guy. Earlier this month, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein barred Rashid Khalidi, director of Columbia's Middle East Institute, from again
title: Metro Matters; Some Limits On Speech In Classrooms

body: DISCO was dead, but the floor lived on. In the early 1980's, I played bass in a band called the Zones. There were five of us, and we all went to Edward R. Murrow High School in Midwood, Brooklyn. We did a lot of shows, had a little following, but the performances I remember most vividly were the three that we played in Bay Ridge at 2001 Odyssey.
title: CITY LORE; Their Small Piece Of a Famous Floor

body: A central figure in the wide-ranging investigation of judicial and political corruption in Brooklyn, a man accused of arranging bribes in divorce and child custody cases for people in the borough's Orthodox Jewish communities, pleaded guilty yesterday to 13 counts of bribery and conspiracy. The man, an electronics dealer named Nissim Elmann,
title: Brooklyn Corruption Figure Admits He Arranged Bribes

body: ONE afternoon in late November, Ronn Torossian, a midlevel publicist with high-level ambitions, stood in front of the Fox Network studios at 48th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, fresh from another foray into the news media. He had just appeared live on ''Your World,'' a business program, to discuss a scandalous brawl that had taken place at
title: Brash P.R. Guy Grabs Clients, Ink

body: While many restaurants will be featuring menus dripping with Champagne and chocolate for Valentine's Day tomorrow, these places will be providing a haven for those who prefer dinner without the hearts and flowers. ARTIE'S NEW YORK DELICATESSEN (212) 579-5959; 2290 Broadway (82nd Street); $; Article: 10/16/02. Artie's may not be in the deli elite,
title: GOOD EATING; Isn't It Unromantic?

body: It might have been just another human triangle in New York, with its elements of almost routine melodrama: the collapse of a marriage; a bitter divorce; the woman moving on and falling in love with a kinder, older man; the former husband's resentments gathering into obsessive jealousy. But the volatile passions that linked three people for months
title: A Triangle Like So Many, But an Ending So Extreme

body: A man stalking his former wife caught up with her on a crowded Manhattan sidewalk last night, shooting her and the man she intended to marry before turning the gun on himself, the police and witnesses said. The shootings, which left the woman and the gunman dead and her companion critically injured, took place at one of Manhattan's most fashionable
title: Gunman Kills His Ex-Wife And Himself Amid Crowds

body: LAWRENCE H. SUMMERS, Harvard's president and chief penitent, came to mind when we learned the other day about New York City's finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search. You no doubt recall the uproar over Mr. Summers's thoughts about why women fare worse than men in math and the sciences. It just might be, he said at an academic conference, that
title: NYC; The Girls Are Smart, Real Smart

body: Students from New York State again dominated the list of 40 finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search announced yesterday. New York had 13 finalists, followed by California, Florida, Illinois and Maryland with four each. Connecticut and New Jersey had none. The contest, founded in 1942 and formerly known as the Westinghouse Science Talent
title: New York Students Dominate Intel Science Contest. Again.

body: MY older brother has spent summers in Turkey every year for almost as long as I can remember, restoring temples and statues. He's intelligent, he gets to travel around the world, and he somehow became the best cook in the family. Not that we have a sibling rivalry or anything. I'm smart enough to know that when my brother wants to turn me on to a
title: $25 AND UNDER; In Midwood, a Taste of Turkey's Countryside

body: In 1994, Community Board 6 in Brooklyn wanted to see how city programs were serving young people in the district. So its youth coordinator did research, and reported back. Eleven years later, the board wanted to revisit the subject. But now there is no youth coordinator, and no money to hire one. Frustrations like this have prompted Board 6, which
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; A Community Board Rattles the Tin Cup

body: Mandarinquat is the clunky if accurate name coined for this small citrus hybrid, a cross between a mandarin orange and a kumquat (shown left at twice its size). It is similar to calamansi, an ancient Asian cross between the two fruits that is rounder and often green, and tastes pretty much the same. Each mandarinquat yields a generous tablespoon of
title: FOOD STUFF; A New Hybrid Citrus Finds Its Way To the Table
